Award.AwardTitle: Exploring Exchange Interactions at Perovskite Oxide Interfaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: This project focuses on the development of new artificial layered materials that advance the fundamental understanding of nanoscience at the atomic level. These materials have applications in next generation devices (spintronic and orbitronic) which have been predicted to display significant improvements in device speed and energy efficiency over conventional electronic devices. The key lies in harnessing the unexpected physical phenomena that result from the changes in structure and chemistry which occur over nanometer scales at surfaces and interfaces of perovskite oxides. Outreach activities include support for the UC Davis Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics Transfer Day which targets educationally disadvantaged and underrepresented groups from Mathematics Engineering Science Achievement programs in Northern California.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: The goal of this project is to develop a fundamental understanding of interfacial phenomena such as exchange coupling interactions at interfaces between ferromagnetic and antiferromagnetic layers. Perovskite oxides are ideal candidate materials for these studies due to their wide range of functional properties that result from the strong coupling between the charge, spin, orbital, and lattice degrees of freedom. In addition, they possess a large number of cations and growth parameters that can be used to manipulate their properties. The approach of this work utilizes laser-assisted growth to control interfacial properties with atomic layer precision in combination with state-of-the-art techniques for characterizing their structural, chemical, and functional properties over multiple length scales. In addition, geometric confinement effects as these materials are patterned down to nanoscale dimensions are being investigated. These results are enabling the development of predictive models of the emergent interfacial properties at dimensions relevant for device applications The participating graduate and undergraduate students are gaining hands-on training in disciplines that lie at the intersection between the traditional fields of Materials Science and Engineering, Physics, and Electrical Engineering through the introduction to state-of-the-art synthesis, sophisticated characterization techniques, and theoretical calculations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As electronic devices continue to play an increasing role in our everyday lives, it has become necessary to ensure that they operate faster, with greater energy efficiency and fault tolerance, while being packaged into a smaller footprint. A proposed solution to achieving these goals is through next generation spintronic devices which operate not only based on the charge of an electron, but also on its spin. This project focused on developing new artificial layered materials that have the desired properties needed for such spintronic devices. In particular, we investigated on a class of materials called perovskite oxides which display a wide range of fascinating functional properties include ferromagnetism, ferroelectricity, and superconductivity. Our work relied on the controlled growth of layered materials using pulsed laser deposition, which allowed us to harness the unexpected physical phenomena that result from the changes in structure and chemistry which occur over nanometer scales at their surfaces and interfaces. A suite of sophisticated characterization techniques, including high resolution electron microscopy and synchrotron radiation-based methods, were utilized to probe the resulting electronic and magnetic properties. With these tools, we developed the measurement protocols needed to characterize the antiferromagnetic properties of artificially layered materials, and we found that these properties differed dramatically from what is observed in bulk materials without a high density of interfaces. In other work, we demonstrated the methodology to extract fundamental magnetic parameters from within patterned microstructures with sub-100 nm spatial resolution. These spatially varying parameters resulted in unique magnetic spin textures not found in other magnetic materials. This fundamental understanding will enable the design of spintronic devices with properties tailored for each application.

A major outreach activity supported by this program was the UC Davis Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM) Transfer Day hosted by the UC Davis Mathematics, Engineering, Science Achievement (MESA) Center. This one-day event brings MESA community colleges from across northern California to UC Davis to see firsthand the type of educational, research, and extracurricular opportunities that are available at a major research institution. These MESA programs have a proportionally higher percentage of students who identify as underrepresented minorities, women, and first generation college attendees. In recent years, the STEM Transfer Day event has grown to over 250 participants and has established book scholarships to matriculating UC Davis students who transferred from community college.
